newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Arnotts extortion threat over - police.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Arnotts extortion threat over - police.

text.p: BRISBANE, Feb 25 (Retuer) - Queensland Police Detective Superintendent Ron Pickering said on Tuesday police were confident there was no longer a threat to food items as a result of the extortion threat against bakery group Arnotts Ltd.
"Police and other interested agencies are confident that there is no longer a threat to foodstuffs as a result of this incident," Pickering told a news conference.
However, Pickering warned consumers to be careful.
"As far as our investigations are concerned, we are confident it (the threat) is over...but the public need to be cautious about the product they purchase," Pickering said.

Pickering said police had reached the decision on the basis that the extortionist had not contacted them since issuing the threat on February 3. "Last Thursday, we decided to wait until Monday for any further contact from the extortionist. No contact was made," he said.
The public appeal for the extortionist to stop by convicted murderer Ron Thomas, who the extortionist says is innocent and should be freed, was also a factor, Pickering said.

However, police said they would continue their investigation into the extortion. "We are still treating this extortion as a major investigation," said New South wales police superintendent Jock Milroy.
Arnotts, which withdrew all its products from supermarkets in New South Wales and Queensland on February 14, is due to hold a press conference at 2.30 p.m. Brisbane time (0430 GMT).

The extortionist threatened to poison biscuits made by Arnotts, Australia's largest biscuit maker, in the states of New South Wales and Queensland unless police involved in Thomas' case took a lie detector test.
The extortionist said police lied in giving evidence that resulted in Thomas serving two life sentences for a 1991 double shooting murder he did not commit.
Arnotts, which has dumped millions of packets of biscuits, has said the extortion threat would cost it A$5.0 million (US$3.8 million) a week in sales.
Shares in Arnotts, about 70 percent owned by Campbell Soup Co, were steady at A$8.90 at 1.10 p.m. (0210 GMT) on Tuesday.
